meditation, whether you're ready for it or not, and you've discovered that the source of the pain
is something that's accumulated over a long period of time, and therefore it's kind of really ingrained
in some muscle systems, and you've just begun to touch some of this, how do you suggest releasing
this kind of accumulated grief, pain?
Just use one of the body awareness techniques. Either label it or sweep through it. Experiencing
it as it presents itself in the present with equanimity is a very important part of releasing
it. There may be other aspects, like acting out, or psychotherapy, or things like that,
but insofar as meditation goes, you just apply the technique to it as it comes up. It doesn't
matter how deep it is. You just keep applying the technique to it. Yes?
This might be a little abstract, but I'm curious. If each pain sends out ramifications all over the
body, then there really is no way, even if you say I've got a stomach ache, it may not actually be a
stomach ache. It might be something else that happens to be manifesting more in the stomach?
I don't know about that. I mean, there is what's called referred pain. You know, you could have an
ache in your shoulder, could come from a tooth or something like that, but by and large, what I was
speaking of is more wherever you feel the pain, it's going to be sending radiation subtly to other
areas. Or it will make its influence felt, if only subtly in other parts of the body. Yes. Okay.
Yeah, Victor? I think you've mentioned, or I've heard mention of that, you know, loving something,
loving it to death. Yes. When these impurities do come up, or this moment, is that something that
you would do, or you would just, in other words, when do you love something, and when don't, you just let it?
Well, actually, loving something to death represents a certain extreme degree of letting it do its
thing. That's what we mean by loving something, means our object of love is the one thing in the
universe that we feel we can be completely hands-off with. You don't have to do anything. We're totally
open to that person, at least for certain moments. We're as open to that person as we are to anything.
So that's called love. So when the impurity presents itself as a mind-body state, if you are
as open to that mind-body state as you could be to anything, have no resistance to it, then that's
loving it to death. You give it all the time and space it needs to play itself out in the mind and
body. That's loving it to death. Yes. I'm not sure that this is the same that it might be. I've experienced
something that seems like, you know, not wanting to be in my skin, and if impurities are resistance, it feels
like it's wave motions. It's energy waves that are trying to move through. What happens is that the
energy waves encounter the impurities, and that creates a kind of pressure. And if you just flow
with the energy waves, then they will, for you, they will break up the impurities. They'll do the work
for you. Oh, that's right. As they do that, you'll feel like you're being run over by a steamroller.
Okay? And you have to be willing to lie down and sort of relax, relax as though you were like
sleeping safe in bed, but and then let the steamroller run over you. Yeah. What's causing
the herky-jerky solidified quality is that there is a free flow of natural energy, chi, that is
trying to express itself, and it's banging up against the impurities. Let it. Let it bang up
against the impurities until it wears them away. Yeah. Go ahead. Do you know?
Just sitting still is what we might call the minimal case of meditation. Okay? The point I
was trying to say is that, I mean, naturally, if you could do your technique, that's the best. But
if you can't, just sitting there has some productivity to it. From what I've seen,
like among the American Indians, over my now many years, almost a decade, I guess more than a decade
of fairly intimate involvement with the Native American practices here, if I had to characterize
the overall, you know, what it's been in overall, what it has basically been is an awful lot of time
sitting around waiting. Michal understands what I'm saying. It's just a lot of waiting, a lot of
driving in cars to get to places, a lot of waiting around once you've gotten to the places, a lot of
waiting around for other people to complete their ceremonies, just a lot of just sitting, empty time.
And I think that within the context of that culture, that's where a lot of the transformation
takes place. I was wondering, earlier in our guided meditation, you were saying about the body
desires and wanting your attention. If you could talk a little bit more about that and explain that
further. Well, basically what it wants is, it wants to be paid attention to it, it wants equanimity.
Mindfulness and equanimity are to feeling, you know, what, to the feeling body, what food is to
the material body. It nurtures it. You come to realize that in time. Okay, our time has come.
